After watching this video, I started thinking about not only how our brain works, but also different things that happen during the process. I never really paid attention that our brain works in different ways which are called fast and slow. It was very interesting for me that the fully engagement of the slower thinking makes your brain turn almost colorblind. As you are concentrated to an object, which makes you think deeper, thus, your brain ignores other details around it. I did not notice this until after watching the video. In fact, when one sees an object, they can figure what the object is. Although for example the math problem, when you try to solve it, your brain travels from the fast thinking into slower thinking. Thank you for such interesting videos with some great examples.

For the 19×26
In my brain, I did 9×6= 54 and carried the 5, held that in my head, (9×2)+5 = 23, so 9×26 is 234. Then next, first the 0 holds the place, 1×6 goes into the tens place, 1×2 goes into the hundreds place, making 10×26 which is obviously 260, next take the other answer, 260+234= 494. Just try to force your brain to memorise the numbers so you're able to multiply. If it were a 3 digit number × a 3 digit number, it'd be possible but REALLY hard so it would be better to do it on paper. It really isn't that complicated it's just multiplying twice and adding it, so the people that got the answer right and thinks they're special, no you aren't, a child could do it.

When testing the system 2 thing, I noticed the color change, and was able to keep up with the adding 1 to each number, but I didn't notice how the numbers changed on the right, because I wasn't focused on it. I noticed the color change only because I realized the color was becoming less apparent, so for a split second, my attention shifted to it, whereas the changed numbers on the right stayed a blob of orange and black. With the animals of each kind, well, I don't exactly associate Noah with ark, as I never watched the movie, nor have I gone into depth with it, and I was stuck on the fact that you said "of each kind" before you continued. (Trying not to spam you with tons of different comments.) And with the "Ann approached the bank," my mind was waiting for you to finish explaining it before it created an image in my head as I am an adept reader and often found that I can sometimes not know what is going on until I finish a sentence or paragraph, so I tried to change exactly how I viewed things in my head. That is to say it doesn't work when someone else is reading or telling me a story. And then, with the soap-soup thing, immediately seeing the blank space in the word, I paused and tried to think of any letter I know that would fit into the space, of course, I only know 2 letters, which were shown not long after I thought of them.
Mmk, I'm done sharing my experience with this video. Honestly, I was trying so hard not to use text implications.

I noticed the colour change, I didn't notice the digits changing. I guess because I assumed they wouldn't so my brain discarded that as unnecessary information that was already "dealt with". I got the bat and ball one really wrong. I got the Noah one correct, sort of... I at least knew that caught that he said Moses and that wasn't right, but then I forgot Noah's name. Also, I read his "ABC" as "A13C" and was quite confused! XD And I didn't picture a woman approaching a bank, my brain ignored that ( probably still hung up on the "A13C" and trying to figure out what the letters and numbers meant. ) I think if anything the central sentence was being analyzed for being an acronym or some sort of word puzzle. Also, to be fair I've visited about as many bodies of flowing water as financial institutions, it's more like I've just been taught to associate the financial institution with the word "bank", rather than the edge of the river which probably would've come to mind as "shore". Also the priming bit was interesting... I don't think my brain is quite normal, though. This instance, and indeed most instances, of priming work on me just fine but it fails noticeably more often than for most. It's why I have difficulty picking up on context of a situation intuitively and often have to ask for repetition and why I need orders to be as direct, literal, and contextualized as possible. I've genuinely done the wrong thing when told to do something because I failed to pick up on what I was being asked to do.

What's even more interesting is, a huge factor in how people decide what is entertaining, is based off of how much information they have to "understand". You need to be able to process what you're being told in order to store it into your long term memory. This is why Asap science is so popular, they effectively use 2 of our senses simultaneously to convey information in a way that most people can understand it.  The same applies to the English language, it's up to the speaker to make his communication as clear as possible to be understood. And we perceive a language as entertaining when it's clear. For example Monotone is boring because it doesn't express emphasis and thus its missing more the half of the meaning.

This video talks about the 2 ways in which human brain thinks. Fast and Slow thinking are the two systems.
Fast thinking is refers to something we see everyday, certain actions people perform or intiutions where the situtation does not really require an explanation rather it is self explanatory. In this brain relates the context to past experiences unconciously and concludes with a statement.
Slow thinking refers to something which cannot be processed by the brain in seconds, something which might require meaning explaination. Here the brain doesnot process information unconciously rather it takes control and can modify behavoiur.

The correct answer to the question about Moses and the Ark is 2. Noah built a boat called an ark, but Moses built an ark, too. The Ark of the Covenant. Inside the ark of the covenant he placed the 2 stone tablets on which the 10 (originally 12) commandments were written. But on the lid of the ark of the covenant were 2 cherubim. Cherubim is a kind of angel, but in the Bible described as having different animal faces and such. If there is anything wrong with the question, it is assuming that cherubim are animals rather than semi divine beings. Sorry, AsapSCIENCE, but choosing Moses was a bad example. :-D

you can't just add 1.00 and ¢10 if the bat is 1.00 MORE than whatever the  ball is, you can't forget there is still the price of the ball to add (∩_∩)

for the bat and ball problem here is the explanation:
1.00 is added to whatever the ball is. If the ball were ¢10, you have to add $1.00 to that to get the price of the bat which is $1.10 The total price of both the ball and the bat is $1.10, so if the bat is $1.10 and the ball is ¢10 then that goes over the limit. The way to fix this is have the ball be ¢5 so we can add 1 dollar to that to get the price of the bat.
Math: bat is $1.05 and ball is ¢5, add together you get $1.10
Answer: ball is ¢5

The fatal misconception is , because fast thinking, is fast, it is not important.   This is a dangerous farce - especially, when considering the important role (automaticity) speed plays in complex systems.  In short, the ultimate goal of fast thinking, is to allow distant ideas to be pulled together in novel permutation.   It is the foundation (pre-analytic) of relational thought.  The day IQ tests are designed to respect the free selection of ideas, and stop forcing pre-arranged sets (example: number patterns), we will have better measures of empirical creativity which combined with analytical components of thought, allow for abstract thought

For all the people saying the bat and ball problem is wrong:

You have a ball and a bat. These two together cost 1.10. You know that the bat costs 1 dollar more than the ball.
So you have:
bat=ball+1 (1)
bat+ball=1.10 (2)
(2) =(1)=> 1+ball+ball=1.10 => 1+2*ball=1.10 => 2*ball=0.10 => ball=0.10/2 => ball=0.5 (3)

So (2) =(3)=> bat+0.5=1.10 => bat=1.05

This is stuff you'd do in middle school!

PSA! To help all you slow pokes out there. (FYI I do not fancy myself super smart or amazing for "figuring this out". I am only trying to help those stuck on it to realize how simple it is to understand.)

- We have a total of 1.10$ to work with.
- If you allow 5 cents out of the 10 cents to be the balls price,
- Then you have 1.05$ left over to be the price of the bat! 
- MEANING that 1 dollar and 5 cents is exactly ONE dollar MORE than the ball's price (which was 5 cents)!

I don't think that these so called scientist, that believe that they are the most objective, give human the human body, especially our brain enough credit. I don't believe that science was invented to criticize our brains, but just to help us where we fall short (absolute objectivity).

It is not a question that human beings are incapable of being objective; we just make mistakes sometimes. And even when we make mistakes, there is still a bit of facts in our original calculations. "Yes! The Earth is round, but it still feels flat. Flat enough that a ball won't keep rolling on the ground. Flat enough that Earth's gravity can be used to construct a perfectly straight ruler for making perfectly straight buildings."

 These wanna be scientists believe that they have a "virgin brain". They never experienced the pleasures of subjectivity. If you listen them you will see that they are grounded in what they so called researched. For example, they believe that a big bang created the universe. How on God's planet did they manage to discover that. If that happened zillion of years ago, what traces of it was left back for them to prove it. They also say that the universe is expanding. And some even say that the Universe will expand so much until it explodes. What a bunch of intellectual nut jobs.

Not to say that they don't make good discoveries, but they are becoming like religious people. Believing in something that they have no proof for. Alright! God is good for your hearts and minds. What good is an exploding Universe... 

I must finally end by saying, the human brain is capable of more than these jerks give it credit for. Human beings can walk and run, while robots are struggle to even creep. Coodos  to our brain. We adapt to our situations, we don't need to be programmed, our calculation ability is as good or even better than computers, ask Daniel Timman. We just do all of this calculations unconsciously. If we weren't able to calculate massive data, we wouldn't breath properly, walk properly, transmit and use neurotransmitters properly. We would be handicapped. 

If you don't believe in the power of the brain, take up Chess. Human beings are still able to analyse positions and form strategical plans better than computers.

My own thoughts about it is, that there is endless stream "Commands" of thoughts, and your fast processor can handle and process those "commands" fast, like muscle movements, eye blinking and some things in your unconscious mind. Then there is this main processor "slow thinking" which can analyse any of those commands slowly. Those "command lines" come in our brain trough our 5 senses as command combinations all the time very fast, but your slow thinking mind can only process 1 of them at time and its always active. It slowly process 1 of them, then move to second etc. That could mean, that universe is actually lot faster than it seems to be. What I'm interested in is the question that can those mental processes that are at first governed by slow thinking be gradually transferred to the domain of fast thinking by practice? We need to figure out the cost of the ball. Let the ball be equal to x. The bat is one dollar more than the ball, so let the bat be equal to 1 + x.

(1 + x) + x = 1.10
2x + 1 = 1.10
2x = .10
x = .05

For all those who find the BAT and BALL problem confusing:
1) The bat costs 1 dollar more than the ball.
2) Everything has to cost 1.10 dollars.

A) The bat costs 1.00 dollar and the ball costs 0 cents. = 1.00 dollars
    - 1) is fulfilled - 2) is not, because the result is not 1.10 dollars

B) The bat costs 1.00 dollar and the ball costs 10 cents = 1.10 dollars
    - 1) is not fulfilled because the difference is 0.90 dollars - 2) is fulfilled

We need to find a way to add 10 cents to THE DIFFERENCE without compromising THE RESULT of B).

The only way is to take OUT 5 cents from the ball and put them INTO the price of the bat. In this way we have:

C) The bat costs 1.05 dollars and the ball costs 5 cents. = 1.10 dollars
    - 1) is fulfilled - 2) is fulfilled

Of course, C is the ONLY correct result, B is the result of fast thinking for most people, and A...that should not even be an answer :)

seriously? didn't you learn anything about equations? let's get this straight. first, let's assume B1 is the cost of the bat, and B2 is the cost of the ball. so, B1 + B2 is 1.10, right? but we also know that the bat costs exactly 1.00 more than the ball, so we can also assume B1 =B2+1.00. so, substituting the value of B1 in B1+B2 =1.10 for B2+1.00, we get B2+1.00+B2 =1.10. Simplifying, we get 2*B2+1.00 =1.10. therefor, 2*B2 =0.10 and B2 = 0.5. so, if the ball costs 0.05, the bat costs 1.05.

Similarly, if you raise a child with emotional apathy, the same behavior crops up. When the human brain develops normally, we're actually fairly peaceful.

For this to be possible, the brain would have had to evolve on a very particular idea of morality. This type of brain goes against evolutionary pressures, because it would have to cease identifying and categorizing creatures once they are considered human. Because the bat one dollar more than the ball.  Thus, bat=ball+1, and bat+ball=1.1.  Thus (ball+1)+ball=1,1. -> 2(ball)+1=1.1 -> 2(ball)=.1 -> ball=.05
Now, if we plug the price of the ball into the first equation, we get the price of the bat:
bat+.05=1.1 -> bat=1.05.  Thus, the bat is $1.05, and the ball is $0.05.

When you are about to fall asleep, your muscles relax. Your brain also begins to shut off neurotransmitters. However, if a muscle relaxes and part of the brain is still "awake", meaning consciously active, you can feel this muscle relax and it feels as if it has no support. This is also why you get a mass muscle twitch when you experience this: Your conscious brain feels that there is no support and thinks "we must be falling!". This sends out a massive signal, to make all your muscles twitch.

Cost of the bat + cost of the ball = $1.10.
Cost of the bat = Cost of the ball + $1.00.
So by substitution,
Cost of the ball + $1.00 + cost of the ball = $1.10
So,
Cost of the ball + cost of the ball = $0.10
Cost of the ball = $0.05

Its not a trick question at all. If you say that X represents the price of the ball

X + (X+1.00) = 1.10 ---- simplify
2X + 1.00 = 1.10 ----- subtract 1 from each side
2X = .10 ------- divide by the 2
X = .05

Not a trick question, just simple mathematics.

He says that the Bat is $1 MORE than the Ball. 
Bat= Ball + $1. 
$1.10 = Bat + Ball. 
Substitute the first equation into the second you get $1.10 = Ball +Ball + $1.
Solve this for (2 x balls) = 10 cents. So one ball is 5 cents. Put back into first equtaion gets you the value of the bat.

19*26 = 20*26 = 2*26*10 = 520-26 = 494.

Going in reverse, though it takes place easily in my head is far more complicated, but I've posted enough now. I think another 3 or 4 posts on top of that just to explain the process of division in my head (regardless of the fact that it takes about the time of a blink and a half to pass through my brain) would be a mite much.

Multiplying and dividing are a little complex to explain.  I have rules (made note of the patterns of in other words) for multiplying or dividing using the the base numbers 0-9, and at the same times use the method of adding for multiplication and the methods of subtraction for dividing. Though depending upon the situation I may employ multiple methods at once.

Using 19*26 is 494 as an example I might do:

19*26 = 10*20 + 10*6 + 9*20 + 9*6 = 494 or what happened in this specific case:

Subtracting, the numbers separate again, but in a different way looking for a common point and adding the difference. For example, looking at 148-89 my brain sees 100 is in between them. My brain takes the 48 above 100 and removes it from the 89 and then calculates down from 100 using the remaining 41 giving me 59.

Especially for multiplication and division there are many unnoticed (or at least unmentioned by all the math teachers I ever had) patterns that make doing those 2 easy as hell.

In the time it takes most to think what the number they are looking at are my brain does multiple calculations for every problem.

Adding, my brain separates each column (ones, tens hundreds, etc.), adds them separately and then adds all the results together giving me the answer that way.

Also for that first problem... 19*26 is 494. Math eventually ended up boring me since it was so easy and I can focus so well that I was into college level math before I hit double digits.

My brain does basic calculations without a real thought because at 6 I memorized the taught rules of numbers they gave us for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing in first grade and made up my own.

I thought A, one, three, C, like some kind of code. I also read the bottom as thirteen and I didn't picture anything for the bank thing at all.

Most of the illusions were nonsense to me. Some because I'd seen them before but mostly because my brain works different from others. Due to Aspergers I notice changes readily and anything I've learned is essentially eidetically stored (I just have to care about it).

$1.00 + $0.10 = $1.10,

Solved algebraically! 
x + ($1.00 + x) = $1.10
Combine like terms.
$1.00 + 2x = $1.10 
Subtract the dollar from each side.
2x = $0.10
Solve for x: 
x = $0.05

If it's $.10, then the bat would cost $1.10, so adding them would cost $1.20.

If the ball is $.05, then the bat would cost $1.05, so adding them would cost $1.10 as expected by the equation.

This problem is most easily solved using guess-and-check, but the algebraic method to solve it is:
n + (n + 1.00) = 1.10
2n + 1.00 = 1.10
2n = 0.10
n = 0.05

The bat itself would have to be $1.10 for it to be a dollar more than the ball, being $0.10, giving you a total of $1.20. The total of both bat AND ball is $1.10, so in order for the price of one to be a full $1 higher than the other, the ball would be $0.05 and the bat $1.05, giving you the total of $1.10.

If the ball was 0,10 and the bat was 1 dollar then the bat would be only 0.90 more then the ball which is wrong.
The right answer is the bat is 1.05 which makes it 1 dollar more then the ball which costs 0.05.

if the ball were 10 cents, and the bat was $1 more than it, then the bat would be $1.10, right? $1.10 + 10 cents = $1.20 which is wrong. 
if the ball was 5 cents, then the bat would be $1.05. $1.05 + 5 cents=$1.10 which is correct.

Hey guys

Your pupils change size to allow more or less light in, depending on how bright your environment is. When it is very dark, your pupils expand to allow as much light as possible to reach your retinas. However, it takes a moment for them to change size, so when your turn on the lights, your retinas get overloaded because too much light is hitting them.

A phenomenon known as Light Adaptation. It takes a few seconds for pigment from surrounding Pigment epithelial cells to protect the Rods and Cones (the light-sensitive cells of the Retina) from the excess light. Till then too much light stimulation hits the Cones and it dazzles you.

We know the Bat is $1.00 more than the ball. So...

Bat=X+$1.00 

Ball=X

The equation is now: (X+$1.00) + X = $1.10

Let's remove one dollar from the total, because we know that $1.00 "belongs" to the Bat. 

Now, we have ten cents left over and we have two Xs. Divide the ten cents in half (which equals five cents) and give five-cents to each X. That makes X=$0.05

Bat = ($0.05 + $1.00) = $1.05
Ball = ($0.05) = $0.05

Makes sense?

When you transition between different waves in the sleep cycle, sometimes you will be partially or even fully woken up. Most people simply immediately fall back asleep, but sometimes there are strong pulls in opposite directions such that one part of your brain is in Slow-wave sleep, and the other is in a state of wakefulness. This can result in night-terrors, sleep walking/talking, etc. You typically have no recollection of the events afterwards.

You throat diverges into three branches, near the base of your neck: Two go to your lungs (trachea), one to the stomach (esophagus). There are muscles which close and open them so that breathing air doesn't go in your stomach and food/drink doesn't go in your lungs (usually). While breathing, your stomach is closed off, so any gases created by your food, or released by carbonation, is trapped in your stomach until you release it all at once, in a belch.

If we're talking pure air, then it, as a medium, could slow light, but not alter it's path. At the microscale, the math dictates that the highest probability path of the light after interacting with one of the molecules in air (O2, N2, etc) is in the same direction as when it hit. At the macro, think of light as a wave. Visible light is on the order of hundres of nanometers, and the air molecules are just a few nanometers (if that), so they hardly interact. Thus air is clear regardless of motion

System 2 is very useful, but sometimes it can work to our downfall.  
If you present two art pieces to a group of art experts and just normal people, and ask which is better, the average individual tends to still have the same opinion as an art expert.  But ask them to say which is better and explain, and suddenly those inexperienced in art will often have a huge difference.  That's why sometimes "going with your gut", or first instinct, is even a good idea from a scientific perspective!

When we analyse the DNA of living animals we see very small differences between similar animals like horses and donkeys and larger differences between very distinct animals. If you map those similarities and differences you get a perfect tree of species lineage. The amount of changes is predictable so we can guess when species drifted apart and when their common ancestor must have lived. And that is exactly what we find in the exact rock layers in form of fossils all around the world!
